Hello-

Richard Watson at U of Southamption is really smart, nice and talented. He
has worked with a lot of the people from Ken's (excellent) list.

http://www.ecs.soton.ac.uk/people/raw/publications


The group here at Michigan State University also does a lot of Alife work:

Here are some of the major publications that have come out of our lab, to
help you get a sense of the type of work done here:


Adaptive Radiation from Resource Competition in Digital Organisms
Chow S, Wilke CO, Ofria C, Lenski RE, and Adami C
Science 305:84-86 (2004).

The Evolutionary Origin of Complex Features
Lenski RE, Ofria C, Pennock RT, and Adami C
Nature, 423:139-144 (2003).

Evolution of Digital Organisms at High Mutation Rate Leads To Survival of
the Flattest
Wilke CO, Wang J, Ofria C, Adami C, and Lenski RE
Nature, 412:331-333 (2001).

Genome complexity, robustness and genetic interactions in digital organisms
Lenski RE, Ofria C, Collier TC, and Adami C
Nature 400, 661-664 (1999).

More (and popular press write-ups):
http://www.cse.msu.edu/~ofria/home/pubs/

There is also this sister lab at MSU, headed by Erik Goodman:

http://garage.cse.msu.edu/

If you have any questions about our group please feel free to ask.


Alife is also done at IU:

http://www.informatics.indiana.edu/alife/

Good luck! 


Cheers,
Jeff Clune

Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State University

jclune@...




> From: "frayn.michael" <frayn.michael@...>
> Reply-To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
> Date: Wed, 13 Aug 2008 16:41:01 -0000
> To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
> Subject: [neat] Re: Finding a University to do a PhD in Evolutionary &
> Adaptive Networks
> 
> Hi Julian,
> 
> That's great, thanks! That's interesting that you highlighted the fact
> that EASy is more interested in A-Life. I suppose my interests are
> starting to lean more towards A-Life as well... but I'm not well
> versed enough in the subject matter yet to know exactly where it
> deviates significantly from "adaptive neural networks" research.
> 
> Are there other Universities that you feel are more in-line with the
> A-Life focus of the EASy programme?
> 
> Cheers,
> Mike
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Julian Togelius" <julian@...> wrote:
>> 
>> Mike,
>> 
>> You could also look at Simon Lucas' or Riccardo Poli's groups at
>> University of Essex:
>> http://dces.essex.ac.uk/staff/lucas/
>> http://dces.essex.ac.uk/staff/poli/
>> 
>> And I must of course also recommend the institution where me and
>> Faustino Gomez currently work, IDSIA in Lugano:
>> http://www.idsia.ch
>> We do plenty of research in evolutionary computation and related
>> fields, both in Juergen Schmidhuber's and Luca Gambardella's group.
>> 
>> I think you should not constrain yourself to English-speaking
>> countries. Any good research lab will have a very international
>> workforce and outlook, and the working language will be English.
>> Myself, I speak English at work and (very bad) Italian in the
>> supermarkets...
>> 
>> You should only look at funded PhD positions that pay you a salary you
>> can live on. The way it works is that professors apply for grants for
>> specific projects from funding agencies, and if they obtain their
>> grant they employ the best person they can find as a PhD student or
>> postdoc. Typically, it does not matter where you come from (though
>> there are exceptions).
>> 
>> I did my MSc at Sussex as well, and while it is a good program, it is
>> quite ALife-oriented.
>> 
>> Good luck with your studies and research!
>> Julian
>> 
>> 2008/8/12 Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...>:
>>> Mike,
>>> 
>>> I'd guess there are others in the group with similar questions so I
>>> think it's probably useful to the group. (By the way, by "Adaptive
>>> Networks," I assume you are referring to adaptive neural networks?)
>>> 
>>> In any case, another option is the University of Texas at Austin,
>>> which is where I did my Ph.D. under Prof. Risto Miikkulainen, who has
>>> a leading group in the area:
>>> 
>>> http://nn.cs.utexas.edu
>>> 
>>> Another good lab is Prof. Jordan Pollack's DEMO Lab at Brandeis:
>>> 
>>> http://www.demo.cs.brandeis.edu/
>>> http://www.cs.brandeis.edu/~pollack/
>>> 
>>> However, Jordan tells me that he will be renaming and revamping his
>>> lab soon, so it will no longer be called "DEMO." However, it is
>>> undoubtedly still a good place to be.
>>> 
>>> There are some newer places too with groups led by new professors,
>>> including Prof. Bobby Bryant's "Neuroevolution and Behavior
>>> Laboratory" at the University of Nevada at Reno
>>> (http://nebl.cse.unr.edu/) and Prof. Josh Bongard's new group at the
>>> University of Vermont (http://www.cs.uvm.edu/~jbongard/).
>>> 
>>> Prof. Hod Lipson at Cornell formerly worked with Prof. Pollack and
>>> runs the Cornell Computational Synthesis Lab:
>>> 
>>> http://ccsl.mae.cornell.edu/
>>> 
>>> However, that lab is a focused on emergent phenomena in general, with
>>> a broader scope than some of the others.
>>> 
>>> One other important group is Prof. Dario Floreano's Laboratory of
>>> Intelligent Systems. This lab is in Switzerland, so I am not sure if
>>> it conducts its day-to-day work in English (it might), but in any case
>>> it is very prominent in the area:
>>> 
>>> http://lis.epfl.ch/
>>> 
>>> Not all these groups have an explicit focus on neural networks, but
>>> most have done some good work with them.
>>> 
>>> Note that any Ph.D. program in North America should be willing to
>>> support you financially if you get in.
>>> 
>>> ken
>>> 
>>> 
>>> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "frayn.michael" <frayn.michael@> wrote:
>>>> 
>>>> Hello everyone,
>>>> 
>>>> I am about to head over to the University of Sussex (in Brighton,
>>>> England) to do their MSc in Evolutionary & Adaptive Systems.
>>>> 
>>>> However, as I am Canadian, the concept of doing a PhD there is a
>>>> little daunting because of the cost. Unfortunately, I am not aware of
>>>> many other Universities that would be interested in funding a PhD of
>>>> such research focuses (let alone would be able to comprehensively
>>>> support students along the way). This assumes, of course, that my MSc
>>>> is wildly successful and I come up with a research question worthy of
>>>> funding.
>>>> 
>>>> Anyhow, I was hoping that some of the members here might be able to
>>>> point out other Universities (in North America or English-speaking
>>>> Europe) that may be appropriate to do such a PhD in. These are the
>>>> ones I'm familiar with now:
>>>> 
>>>> University of Edinburgh
>>>> University of Sussex
>>>> University of Central Florida
>>>> 
>>>> I realize this isn't directly related to NEAT but I couldn't think of
>>>> a more knowledgeable group on the subject matter a hand. If there
> is a
>>>> more appropriate group, then please just point me in the right
>>>> direction and I'll not post about this again here. Apologies if it's
>>>> too off-topic.
>>>> 
>>>> Cheers,
>>>> Mike
>>>> 
>>> 
>>>
